text: In this first Berserker Kazan video, I'm
going to be giving you guys 10 tips to
help you get off to the best possible
start. There are things I wish I would
have known when I started playing the
scheme. There are a lot of mechanics
that kind of just get thrown at you.
Some of these things you'll figure out
eventually. Some of them you'll wish
you'd known like 20 hours earlier. So,
that's what we're going to get into in
this video. So, the first thing is a tip
about soul tier dust and soul tier stone
shards. There are other consumables that
do the same thing, but these are the
ones you'll find early on. These not
only give you lacrimma, which can help
you level up. Like if you're 200 short,
you can consume one to get enough
lacrimma to level up, which is great,
but they also heal you for health. So,
you can put these on your item bar and
then use them like in a boss fight. If
you run out of netherworld energy to top
you up your health so that you don't die
and you're able to complete the fight.
And one great thing about the first
Berserker Kazan is that when you die in
a boss in this game, you leave your
lacrima outside the boss fight. So you
won't lose that lacria that you gain
from using them either. The next point
is while at any blade nexus, you can go
to Kazan's memories and spend what are
called vengeance points to increase your
stamina damage, damage, and damage
multiplier. These increase in cost as
you put points into them. So you
probably want to spread your points
around early on to get the most impact,
but these can really help your
performance in combat and improve it.
And you gain these points from picking
up notes and collectibles during each
mission, which you kind of do naturally
as you're exploring. So, just don't
forget to spend them periodically. Like,
you might notice it once and then forget
about it because you didn't have any
vengeance points. Make sure you're
checking this periodically and spending
them after you complete missions. The
next tip is that there's a hidden chest
inside the crevice that is located
behind a fake wall that will provide you
with a decent early game armor set
called the executioner set. It's an
excellent all-around set which has good
bonuses for any weapon. Doesn't matter
which weapon type you're using. So, it's
definitely worth getting. I think you
have to complete a few missions before
you can get to it, but as soon as you
can get to it, absolutely pick it up.
The next tip is about acquiring lanterns
that you can get from Danen in the
crevice once you've completed his bonus
mission and he's moved there. These will
help you tremendously in the game. There
are four different lanterns you can get
early on. There's the coward's lantern,
which reveals corruptors, which can kill
you if you're not careful, as well as
undead assassins, which are otherwise
invisible. So, this can help you like
sus out some, you know, dangerous
situations. The Pathfinder's Lantern
reveals hidden walls and it can guide
you to them. Be sure you equip this when
running around on most levels early on
so you don't miss secrets. This is the
one you'll use the most, so I recommend
you getting it first. The Undead Hunter
Lantern prevents undeaden from reviving
after you deplete their health bars.
This is really good for some missions
early on that are undead heavy, and it
can be really nice because that's just a
really annoying mechanic to have to deal
with. But again, these are kind of
expensive, so it's up to you whether you
want that one or the Pathfinder's
lantern early on. The grave robber's
lantern helps you find loot and collect
items that provide vengeance points.
It's probably the least useful of the
four, but it's there if you need it. And
make sure that when you buy lantern that
you put it into one of your item slots
and turn it on while you're exploring,
otherwise you won't gain the effect from
it. And also note that there is a
lantern that you'll get quickly in New
Game Plus that does all four of these
things combined, so you will no longer
have to choose which one to use. The
next tip is that many boss fights
feature a specific status effect like
flame, venom, chaos, or plague. And you
need to watch for the attacks that build
up these statuses on your resistance
bar. Not all of their attacks do, but
these attacks will build up your status
bar even if you guard or bring guard
them. So, be sure to dodge sometimes to
further prevent buildup when you're
facing these attacks. If your bar fills
completely, then you'll trigger that
status, and you want to avoid that. So,
some gear features specific resistances.
So, it can make it harder for bosses to
fill your bar, which prevents the status
effect. And additionally, you can use
resistance elixirs, which are
consumables or cleanse potions to
cleanse a status effect. And if you need
more of these, if you run out, you can
actually go to the blacksmith and craft
them in exchange for transmutation
shards and spirit orbs. The next tip is
use soul stones for health recovery
rather than lacrim gain when you speak
to Defrona and the crevice. Soul stones
are these red glowing crystals you can
find in Smash on each mission. As you
find and smash more of them, you can
speak with Defrona in the crevice and
spend them. We have a separate video
showing all their locations if you need
help finding them, and you can find them
on the wiki as well. When you speak to
Defrona, use your soul stones to gain
health recovery rather than lacria gain
since there are no real easy ways to
upgrade health recovery in the game
besides this, and you can always farm
more lacrima if you need it. This
improves your healing from netherworld
energy and other sources that heal you
like the aforementioned soul tier dust
and soul tier stone shards. One
fantastic thing about the first
Berserker Kazan is that you can teleport
from the crevice to any blade nexus
you've unlocked in any mission. This
allows you to leave a mission before a
boss and buy things or improve your gear
and come back and try again or head back
to the crevice mid mission if you want
to tweak your gear, etc. and come back
to your most recent Blade Nexus. In
piggybacking off this last point, since
you can teleport to any blade nexus
you've been to, this allows you to farm
bosses over and over again by
teleporting to their blade nexus and
engaging them in combat once again. The
reason you will need to do this is that
there are specific crafted sets in Kazon
that require materials from specific
bosses in order to craft. These are not
guaranteed drops, so you'll have to
defeat them many times if you want a
full set, especially for some of the
sets that have up to eight pieces. These
are the best sets in Kazan, so it's
definitely worth doing and can help make
your progress easier moving forward if
you have a wicked set bonus. Danjin also
sells boss set materials if you need
some extra ones, so be sure to check him
periodically as well. NPCs will have new
dialogue or maybe even unlock bonus
missions every time you finish a main
mission. So, check up on them after
every mission because bonus missions
reward you with soul stones, jarlings,
and other loot, and they can help you in
your journey. And not to mention that
there are variations of boss fights that
are fun that you'll miss out on if you
don't do this. And there's extra
dialogue from NPCs. So the side quests
or the bonus missions are a big part of
the game you don't want to miss out on.
This next tip you'll probably have
figured out at this point, but you can
craft the blacksmith, but you'll need
materials in order to make set pieces.
You can craft materials from other
materials at the blacksmith to get ones
you need by going to the craft tab and
going all the way over to the right,
which is not very obvious. And this will
let you get the things you need to craft
the sets that you want. And also don't
forget that you can dismantle gear here
for crafting materials. So if you have
extra gear, consider dismantling it in
order to be able to craft the sets you
want. There are around 50 sets in the
first Berserker Kazan, and each one has
different effects. Many are just armor
sets, but some include weapons as well,
like a great sword or spear. Acquiring
these sets is pretty straightforward,
but understanding what they do and if
they're the right set for you is not
always as easy. Be on the lookout for
sets that match your preferred weapon
type and find the ones that best suit
your play style. Some give bonuses to
specific skills which are shown in
brackets. And if you're using those
skills, this can benefit you a lot.
However, if you don't use those skills,
then these would not be good for you.
Make sure to check your skill trees
periodically to familiarize yourself
with these skills so you understand what
is being boosted by your sets.
Additionally, many sets let you learn a
new skill if you have enough pieces that
will show up on your skill tree for that
weapon type. You can't see what these
skills do without having the full set
equipped, but we do have them all shown
on the wiki. So, if you want to look
there and decide if they're worth
farming or not before you spend the
effort, you are free to do so. After
you've acquired an entire set, you will
likely outlevel it eventually and will
need to upgrade it in order to increase
its level. This provides more damage for
weapons and more defense for armor.
Prioritize weapons first and then
improve armor afterwards. And note that
light and medium armor doesn't improve
in defense much per level compared to
heavy armor. You can do this at Oxana in
the crevice by sacrificing unused
weapons and armor. Just make sure you
don't sacrifice something that you plan
on using later. Note that once you get
far enough into the game that you can
craft epic versions of weapons, some
will have a fixed attribute that will be
a new skill in its own right. We also
have these on the wiki if you'd like to
see them, or you can check out our
YouTube video as well to see if they're
worth crafting or not. And the last tip
is that there's something called agility
in the first Berserker Kazon that
impacts stamina recovery and dodge cost.
The higher your equip weight percentage,
the lower your agility will be, reducing
your stamina recovery and increasing
your dodge cost. These rank from A to D.
So A being the best, having the highest
stamina recovery, and lowest dodge cost,
D being the worst, having the worst
stamina recovery and increased dodge
cost. The trade-off is that heavier
armor that's going to increase your
equip weight provides better defense,
and it also reduces the stamina damage
you take when getting hit. So, if you
want to take less damage when you're
getting hit, you're going to be wearing
heavy armor, and that's going to reduce
your agility. It's important to note,
though, that strength and vitality both
reduce your total weight percentage,
allowing you to have better agility and
heavier armor. Great swords actually
scale the best with a strength stat, so
players utilizing great swords should
have good mobility even when they're
wearing some of the heaviest armor in
the game. Dual blades benefit from
strength, and it also increases their
damage, but not as much as great swords.
So, dual blades players will probably
opt for medium armor to keep their
mobility high and have a good balance
between mobility and protection. Spears,
on the other hand, don't benefit from
strength at all. It doesn't improve the
damage of spears, so they'll probably
have to wear light armor in order to
keep their agility high. The break
points for agility are as follows. Below
60% is A, below 75% is B. Below 100% is
C, and then finally D is above 100%. You
want to try and stay in the A and B
range if you can. C and D are really
bad. So, that wraps up my 10 tips for
the first Berserker Kazan. I hope you
found these things useful. A lot of
these things you'll figure out in your
journey over time, but if you knew them
at the beginning of the game, it could
save you a lot of time, which is why I
mentioned them here. As always, if there
are other tips for new players, things I
forgot to mention if you're playing the
game, you can leave them there as well.
And if you have questions about
mechanics, maybe something doesn't make
sense to you, you can leave them in the
comments and I will try and answer your
questions as soon as I can.
[Music]
[Music]
[Music]
